headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: What Happened in Georgia. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: SARA MURRAY, CNN POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Until very recently.

utterances.speaker: PAULA REID, CNN SENIOR LEGAL AFFAIRS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, Sara Murray, thank you so much. I know I will be tuning in and others should, too, for this all-new episode of "THE WHOLE STORY WITH ANDERSON COOPER." It's one whole story, one whole hour. It airs next only on CNN.And thanks for joining me this evening. I'm Paula Reid. Have a great evening.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to THE WHOLE STORY. I'm Anderson Cooper.Former President Donald Trump has already been indicted on federal charges for mishandling classified documents and state charges for hush money payments. He's pleaded not guilty to all charges but he's also the target of another investigation by the Department of Justice appointed special counsel looking into his efforts to subvert election results in seven states. One of those states is Georgia where President Biden flipped blue for a win in 2020. President Trump refused to accept the result and he and his allies engaged in a number of plots to overturn Biden's win. And some of these actions were so aggressive they drew the attention of the Fulton County district attorney who launched her own criminal probe in 2021. Now a grand jury has been convened, and the former president could face even more indictments in the weeks to come. So what exactly did Trump and his allies do in Georgia? And what charges might they face? Over the next hour, CNN's Sara Murray will lay out the entire investigation and piece together what we know about the pressure campaigns, Trump's private calls to election officials, a major data breach and a plot to subvert the electoral college process. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Breaking news in to CNN this hour. Prosecutors in Georgia have opened a criminal investigation.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: -- criminal investigation into former President Trump. Why? Because of his January phone call to the Georgia secretary of state. JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHORadministration of the 2020 Georgia general election. GEOFF DUNCAN (R), FORMER GEORGIA LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR: Donald Trump got beat by Joe Biden handily.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, FORMER PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: There's no way we lost Georgia. That was a rigged election.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: He went on a war path like a scolded child to do anything he possibly could to overturn that election.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They defrauded us out of a win in Georgia. And we're not going to forget it.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: I underestimated his willingness to push the envelope as far as he did, to just boldfaced lie again and again and again.MURRAY (voice-over): Three months after the election, the district attorney in Fulton County, Georgia, Fani Willis, officially opened an investigation into former President Donald Trump's efforts to overturn the state's presidential election results.

utterances.speaker: FANI WILLIS, FULTON COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: This is a criminal investigation. We're not here playing a game. I plan to use the power of the law because I sit here in this jurisdiction. It's my responsibility.TAMAR HALLERMAN, SENIOR REPORTER, ATLANTA JOURNAL-CONSTITUTION: Fani Willis is known as a prosecutor's prosecutor. She's known as a tough cookie who's a real preparer. And she like to say, I don't like to try things skinny. I don't like to be in a courtroom unprepared.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: It's in that vein that Willis requested a special purpose grand jury to assist in her investigation.

utterances.speaker: ROBERT JAMES, FORMER DEKALB COUNTY DISTRICT ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Special purpose grand juries are very -- they're very rare in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Robert James is one of the few district attorneys who has overseen a special purpose grand jury in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: JAMES
utterances.sentences: Their own powers are much broader than a regular grand jury.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: While a special purpose grand jury doesn't issue indictments, it can be a useful tool for a prosecutor.MICHAEL MOORE, FORMER U.S. ATTORNEY: The D.A. wanted it because she wanted to use the powers to subpoena people, to get evidence, documentary evidence that she wouldn't otherwise have access to. Special purpose grand jury would get her more information about specific details of the allegations that she was investigating.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: A special purpose grand jury was empaneled in May 2022. And after nearly seven months and 75 witnesses, they authored a report in December 2022 recommending indictments. The sprawling case has involved some of the biggest names in the Trumporbit as well as some local and state level politicians many of which you may have never even heard of. And this entire investigation stems back to a single phone call.

utterances.speaker: MARK MEADOWS, FORMER WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF
utterances.sentences: OK. All right. Mr. President, everybody is on the line. And just so this is -- this is Mark Meadows, the chief of staff, just so we all are aware.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: To this day, Trump says he did nothing wrong.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Nobody found anything wrong with that perfect call.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: It started on Fani Willis' first full day in the office after she was sworn in as Fulton County's first female district attorney.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: So help me, God.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: Morning of January 4th, she walks in and sets her stuff on her desk and immediately takes note of the story that's dominating cable news coverage that day.

utterances.speaker: FREDRICKA WHITFIELD, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Major breaking news this hour.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Inside a stunning new pressure campaign.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: They are all airing snippets of this extraordinary leaked phone conversation between then President Donald Trump and Brad Raffensperger.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Brad Raffensperger is the secretary of state in Georgia, and one of the few Republicans who publicly stood up against Trump's conspiracy theories and claims of election fraud after losing the 2020 presidential election.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: OK. Thank you very much. Hello, Brad and Ryan, and everybody. We appreciate the time and the call.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Trump was joined by a number of advisers, including Chief of Staff Mark Meadows and conservative attorney Cleta Mitchell.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: If we can just go over some of the numbers I think it's pretty clear that we won. We won very substantially in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: At the time of the election, Gabriel Sterling was the voting system's implementation manager.(On-camera): When did you learn that that call was taking place? GABRIEL STERLING (R), CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER, GEORGE SECRETARY OF STATE'S OFFICE: About 60 seconds before the call took place.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And what was your thought when you learned that he was about to hop on the phone with the president at the time?

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: I was kind of irritated I wasn't on that call. And then I heard the call the next day. I'm like, I'm so thankful I was not on that call. It was an hour of which 55 minutes the president spoke. And it was the greatest hits of all the stuff that we have been debunking for two months.Giving oxygen to this continued disinformation is leading to a continuing erosion of people's belief in our elections. MURRAY (voice-over): Trump appeared to threaten the secretary of state.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You know what they did. And you're not reporting it. That's a -- you know, that's a criminal offense. And you know you can't let that happen. That's a big risk to you.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And then there's this.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I just want to find 11,780 votes which is one more than we have because we won the state.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: 11,780. The exact number of votes Trump needed to win Georgia.(On-camera): How are you taking this in? BRAD RAFFENSPERGER (R), GEORGIA SECRETARY OF STATE: There weren't the votes to find. We had checked out all the allegations. So we knew that we had the right results. MURRAY (voice-over): Raffensperger refused to budge.

utterances.speaker: RAFFENSPERGER
utterances.sentences: Well, Mr. President, the challenge that you have is the data you have is wrong.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: By this time point Raffensperger had overseen three separate ballot counts, conducted many other reviews of the process and investigated more than 250 claims of voter fraud. The fact remained. Trump had lost the state of Georgia.

utterances.speaker: RAFFENSPERGER
utterances.sentences: All I knew is we had to, you know, lean into the law and into the facts. And we had both on our side.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Raffensperger also received a call from Republican Senator Lindsey Graham. The secretary of state left the call believing Graham implied he should try to throw out ballots. Graham denies that claim.

utterances.speaker: RAFFENSPERGER
utterances.sentences: Well, he asked if the ballots could be matched back to the voters. And then I got the sense it implied that, then you could throw those out.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: Then President Donald Trump made phone calls to a handful of elected officials in Georgia in the aftermath of the 2020 elections. He called Frances Watson, who was then an investigator in the Secretary of State's Office.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The people of Georgia are so angry at what happened to me. They know I won. I won by hundreds of thousands of votes. It wasn't close. Whatever you can do, Frances, it would be -- it's a great thing. It's an important thing for the country.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: The former president called Attorney General Chris Carr in December 2020 asking him basically not to get involved as Texas was fighting Georgia's election results at the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Trump made phone calls to officials requesting a special session of the legislature. So Georgia legislators could appoint their own electors instead of the ones for Biden the voters had selected. He called the former speaker of the Georgia House of Representatives.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: David Ralston, a Republican.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And the governor.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: He made at least two phone calls to Governor Kemp.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Both refused to call for a special legislative session.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: There was a very orchestrated, calculated process going on around us in Georgia trying to get us to change our minds and put pressure on us.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: So far we haven't been able to find the people with the courage to do the right thing.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: This is Trump just hours after Governor Brian Kemp declined his request.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Your governor could stop it very easily if he knew what the hell he was doing. He could stop it very easily.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump was intimately involved in every process around trying to overturn this election. I mean, this was a granular ground game of epic proportion. This was somebody obsessed with overturning the election at all costs.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Rudy Giuliani hijacks the Georgia legislature.(On-camera): So he lied?

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: Yes.(COMMERCIAL BREAK) MURRAY (voice-over): For Jen Jordan, December 3rd, 2020, began as she expected. The then Georgia Democratic state senator made her way downtown to the capital for a meeting.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: It was a government oversight meeting to talk about what happened in the elections and the issues. And it ended up being a pretty straightforward committee hearing.RYAN GERMANY, FORMER GENERAL COUNSEL, GEORGIA SECRETARY OF STATE'S OFFICE: We have not seen anything that would suggest widespread fraud or widespread problems.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Here I am thinking, OK, great. We've answered some of these conspiracies. We've dealt with the issues. It felt like an adult committee hearing. So I went to my office. And then I almost immediately get a text. Somebody was, like, you've got to get over to the Capitol. Something is going on.WILLIAM LIGON (R), FORMER GEORGIA STATE SENATOR: Called the subcommittee of the judiciary to order.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Unbeknownst to Jordan, her Republican colleague, then State Senator William Ligon, convened another separate special committee to look into questions of election fraud.

utterances.speaker: LIGON
utterances.sentences: These complaints deserve full investigation.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: And his committee ended up playing host to Rudy Giuliani and many of these election deniers related to the Trump campaign.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I bless you.

utterances.speaker: RUDY GIULIANI, FORMER TRUMP LAWYER
utterances.sentences: I bless you, too.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Don't give up.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: I'm not giving up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Never give up.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We love you, Rudy.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: Distinguished members of the committee, thank you very much for giving us this hearing. I represent President Trump along with Jenna Ellis.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Rudy Giuliani wasn't the only surprise appearance.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The news media were not the usual characters. People like the "Epic Times," Newsmax, OAN, all of these various news outlets that had a very particular view in terms of how they were covering the election post-November. And it was incredibly troubling.MURRAY (on-camera): Do you remember having any other kind of committee proceeding where all of a sudden Newsmax and OAN were there?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: No. No. I mean, why are you flying down from D.C. on December 3rd to the Georgia state capital for some nothing subcommittee hearing? What really triggered serious alarm bells is when the tweet went out from the then president.MURRAY (voice-over): President Trump fired off this tweet to his millions of followers ahead of the hearing. Directing them to One America News Network to watch what would unfold at the Georgia capital. (On-camera): What did that tell you about who the audience was for this production?

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: Those weren't official meetings. I didn't sanction those. Those were just something that had the formality of feeling like official meetings. They wanted a special session because that added one layer of authenticity to their conspiracy theories.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Perhaps the most egregious allegations came in the form of a video. The Trump team presented what they claimed was evidence of fraud from election night ballot tabulating at the State Farm Arena in downtown Atlanta. It purported to show a number of nefarious moments, including sending election observers home to secretly count ballots.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Four people stay behind and continue counting and tabulating well into the night.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: They claimed election workers were pulling out suitcases of hidden ballots after others were sent home.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Once everyone is gone, coast is clear, they are going to pull ballots out from underneath a table.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And scanning ballots multiple times.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: How many ballots went through those machines in those two hours when there was no one there to supervise? We believe that could easily be and probably and certainly beyond the margin of victory.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The story she told was just chilling in terms of look at what they're doing. Video doesn't lie.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: And when you look at what you saw on the video, which to me was a smoking gun.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The problem was that the video had been selectively edited.MURRAY (on-camera): What did you make when you saw what he was showing his video of what happened at the State Farm Arena?

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: They found a magical suitcase full of ballots. When I look at, that's a ballot carrier. Those were sealed ballot carriers, which is a normal thing you'd have in elections. But they sliced that thing down to this one little narrow thing. They intentionally misled the state Senate in order to keep pushing this narrative and try to get the election thrown out.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: He lied?

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, they never backed off from it.MURRAY (voice-over): The FBI and the Department of Justice also got involved in chasing the allegation. Both came to the same conclusion as the Secretary of State's Office.

utterances.speaker: BILL BARR, FORMER ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: My opinion then and my opinion now is that the election was not stolen by fraud.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: There was no illegal activity by the election workers.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: There has to be a villain or the enemy. And in this hearing in particular, the villain really was the election workers in Fulton County.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: There's more than ample evidence to conclude that this election was a sham.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Once that video was made public and misrepresented as evidence of fraud, two of the women counting ballots, Ruby Freeman and her daughter, Shaye Moss, were doxed. Their faces, names, addresses, phone numbers shared online. A Motley Crew emerged phoning Freeman and showing up at her home. Stephen Lee, a pastor from suburban Chicago, parked outside Freeman's house until she dialed 911.

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN LEE, PASTOR FROM CHICAGO
utterances.sentences: Yes. My name is Steve Lee. And I'm a pastor. And I'm also working with some folks who are trying to help Ruby out.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: LEE
utterances.sentences: OK. And also get some truth of what's going on. It would be nice if I could talk to her.

utterances.speaker: RUBY FREEMAN, FORMER GEORGIA ELECTION WORKER
utterances.sentences: I don't talk to nobody.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: OK. So you don't want to talk to him? No? OK.

utterances.speaker: FREEMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm not interested. I have a pastor.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: OK. Yes, ma'am. MURRAYpreviously done work for R. Kelly and Kanye West, also showed up in Georgia. Freeman agreed to talk to Kutti at a police precinct. According to court documents, Kutti allegedly pressured Freeman.

utterances.speaker: TREVIAN KUTTI, PUBLICIST
utterances.sentences: We have probably 48 hours in which to move you.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Offering her protection if she would confess to engaging in election fraud. Even though Freeman had done nothing wrong.

utterances.speaker: KUTTI
utterances.sentences: I cannot say what specifically will take place. I just know that it will disrupt your freedom. You are a loose end for a party that needs to tidy up.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Freeman and Moss later testified in front of the January 6th Committee about vile, racist threats they received.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Giuliani has since conceded as part of a civil lawsuit that he made defamatory statements about the two election workers. Nearly every other Georgia election official who stood up to the lies received similar threats.

utterances.speaker: RAFFENSPERGER
utterances.sentences: The texts, personal cell number was doxed. Personal e- mails were doxed.MURRAY (on-camera): But it wasn't just you. It was your family members?

utterances.speaker: RAFFENSPERGER
utterances.sentences: Yes. My wife mostly. And she got the more vile, you know, personal kind of stuff.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: State patrol and heightened security and bomb sniffing dogs. And there was a Web site that formed that put a picture of my house and my address and my name and my kids' names.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: You should go to jail. You are Judas. You're a traitor. You've committed treason.MURRAY (voice-over): The December 3rd hearing would bring even more chaos to the state in the aftermath of the election when a then little-known attorney appeared. (On-camera): What do you remember about John Eastman's presentation that day?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: I thought it was ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: JOHN EASTMAN, FORMER TRUMP ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: These significant statutory violations are in my view more than enough.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: He saw it as the duty of the legislature to step in basically throw out the will of Georgia voters, and for the legislature to convene a special session and appoint their own Republican alternate electors.

utterances.speaker: EASTMAN
utterances.sentences: I don't think it's just your authority to do that but quite frankly I think you have a duty to do that, to protect the integrity of the election here in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: He didn't have a clue what he was talking about. I'm like, he's wrong. And anybody who can read and especially somebody who purports to be some kind of constitutional, you know, expert, this is -- this does not feel like it's legit.MURRAY (voice-over): The December 3rd hearing wouldn't be the only appearance by Giuliani and other Trump allies in the Peach State. Giuliani appeared at two other hearings in front of the Georgia legislature, in December 2020, where he continued to push the debugged claims of fraud.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: There are 10 ways to demonstrate that this election was stolen, that the votes were phony, that there were a lot of them dead people, felons, phony ballots.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And at the last hearing where Giuliani appeared on December 30th, the Senate subcommittee that State Senator William Ligon chaired released a report with their findings. The first stating, quote, "The November 3rd, 2020 election was chaotic and the results cannot be trusted."

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: That basically regurgitated a lot of those conspiracy theories and half truths about the vote count in Georgia without actually investigating any of those claims. And that report, in turn, ended up being cited by the Trump campaign and many others in their pushes to invalidate election results elsewhere.MURRAY (on-camera): So the report comes out. What kind of weight did that carry?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: It had none. But again, that really wasn't the point. They got that close.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: You get all of the legitimacy, you bet.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The informator of the Georgia State Senate, right? All of it. And they got that close. They got that close.MURRAY (voice-over): Coming up -- (On-camera): So you follow him? (Voice-over): A secret meeting at the capital.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED PROTESTERS
utterances.sentences: Stop the steal!

utterances.speaker: GEORGE CHIDI, JOURNALIST
utterances.sentences: I'm driving by the capital because I'd heard there might be something going on. And as I turn the corner, I see this big black -- I thought it was an SUV. It was an armored personnel carrier. And Alex Jones out of the cupola, at the top, you know, like a dime store Mussolini, just exhorting people like, don't let them take this away from you, off in the distance.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: George Chidi is a Democrat and a local Georgia journalist who reports on politics and crime in his blog, "The Atlanta Objective." He covered the far-right groups that descended on the Georgia capital for Stop the Steal rallies after the 2020 election.

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: And this -- like they filled the stairs and they're talking about taking over the capitol. And I started to think, all right, what exactly are you going to do? There was a conversation that was happening in right-wing spaces about disrupting the electoral count. So I went to the capitol on December 14th.LAUREL M. LEE, SECRETARY, DEPARTMENT OF STATE: If you would please complete your ballots.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: December 14th was the date that the state's electors all across the country would meet to certify their vote.

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I thought maybe the Three Percent militia or some other group were going to show up and do something stupid. And I wanted to bear witness.MURRAY (on-camera): So did you see any of those types when you got to the Georgia state capitol?

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I didn't.MURRAY (voice-over): What Chidi did see was a conservative activist who he recognized from his reporting.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Room 216 at the Georgia state capitol, just one floor below where the Democratic electors were meeting to certify the Georgia vote for President-elect Biden.(On-camera): So you followed him?

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I followed him.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Did you go into the room?

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I went into the room. Then I walked in the door. Hey, what's going on here? What are you doing? Like what, we're having a meeting, and there was a woman's voice. I'm looking around and I've got the thing going. And then she says, "He's got a camera going." And then another fellow comes and just sort of hustles me out. I said, but what is this meeting? And she says it's an education meeting.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: So they told you it was an education meeting.

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: Yes. They all but frog marched me out of the room.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: And then they posted somebody out in front to make sure that nobody else went in.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: So were you convinced it was an education meeting?

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I was convinced it was exactly what I thought it was.MURRAY (voice-over): And what he thought turned out to be right. A group of Republican shadow electors gathered to sign an illegitimate certification for President Trump.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: Many of the Republicans who served as alternate electors that mid-December day were high up figures in the state party.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The State Senator Burt Jones, who is now the lieutenant governor.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Georgia Lieutenant Governor Burt Jones was initially a target of the investigation. But the judge presiding over the special purpose grand jury blocked the district attorney from investigating him after Fani Willis hosted a fundraiser for Jones' then political opponent.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's a what are you thinking moment. The optics are horrific.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: All of the other Georgia Republicans who served as fake electors were labeled targets in the Fulton County investigation, though some were later granted immunity.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: At the head of the table was David Shafer who was the current chair of the GOP in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Shafer played a key role in organizing Georgia's fake slate of electors. He helped secure the room they met in, convened them at the capitol, and served as one of the fake electors.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: Afterwards he said he had acted in response to what the Trump campaign had told him.

utterances.speaker: DAVID SHAFER, FORMER MEMBER, GEORGIA STATE SENATE
utterances.sentences: Because the president's lawsuit contesting the Georgia election has not been decided or even heard, we held this meeting to preserve his rights. Had we not held the meeting, then his lawsuit would effectively be mooted.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Shafer's attorneys said he broke no laws and was following legal advice when he cast a, quote, "contingent ballot for Trump."(On-camera): So what's your impression at that point? Is it like David Shafer has got to come out and say something now because we've caught them?

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I thought so. I thought that's exactly what it was.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: What do you make of that narrative now?

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I've never been thrown out of, you know, a meeting in a public legislative space. That's unheard of. You know, I wasn't being disruptive. They didn't have a good reason to do it. There are no such things as secret meetings at the state capitol. Like that's just not how things work.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: So does that explanation hold water to you?

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: That, you know, we weren't trying to hide anything?

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: I think they absolutely were trying to hide something, at least at first.MURRAY (voice-over): Shafer's attorney told CNN that his client did not try to keep things secret. But that claim is contradicted by an e- mail the fake electors received just 18 hours before they met at the capitol. The e-mail, sent by Robert Sinners, the Trump campaign's Election Day operations lead in Georgia at the time, asked for, quote, "complete secrecy and discretion."

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: He told them to conceal what they were going to do.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The e-mail instructed the fake electors to tell security guards they were attending a meeting with two then state senators, Brandon Beach and Burt Jones. According to the author of the letter, he was directed to send it by Trump campaign lawyers and David Shafer.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: In a process that is probably one of the most public things that the government does, to get an e-mail from somebody saying keep all this secret and under the radar, there's probably no good motive behind it. And I think it's good evidence of intent.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) now regrets his part in the fake elector scheme. In a deposition to the January 6th Committee, he expressed regret for his actions.

utterances.speaker: ROBERT SINNERS, FORMER TRUMP CAMPAIGN STAFFER
utterances.sentences: We were just, you know, kind of useful idiots at that point. You know, a strong part of me really feels that it's just kind of as the road continued and it was failure, failure, failure that that got formulated as what we have on the table, let's just do it. MURRAYof operatives in Trump's orbit outside of the state of Georgia. Much of that laid out from another investigation.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: According to a final report from the January 6th Committee, the motivation behind creating the slate of fake electors in Georgia and other states was to create enough chaos to persuade then Vice President Mike Pence to subvert the Constitution and throw out the 2020 election results on January 6th. The Fulton County prosecutors zeroed in on John Eastman's part in the plot.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: They were very interested in his alleged role at the center of coming up with this scheme of appointing these Republican electors.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The conservative attorney made various unfounded claims of voter fraud when he pushed the plan to overturn Biden's victory to Georgia lawmakers.

utterances.speaker: EASTMAN
utterances.sentences: The constitutional power to decide on the method for choosing electors remains exclusively with the state legislatures.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: New York attorney Kenneth Chesebro was also a focus due to his alleged role coordinating the plan and execution of the fake electors. Chesebro hasn't responded to multiple inquiries from CNN about his actions. His attorney told the "New York Times" the only communication Chesebro had with anyone in Georgia regarding the alternate electors was sending ballot forms to David Shafer. But e-mails released by the January 6th Committee show it was more than just paperwork.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: There was legal structure to this. There was constitutional structure to this. There was logistics, there was secrecy. There is no doubt in my mind that this started in the Oval Office and worked its way outward.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Coming up, inside the plot to seize voting data.

utterances.speaker: ZACHARY COHEN, CNN NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Really a who's who of election deniers.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: All caught on tape.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: About 200 miles southeast of Metro Atlanta sits Coffee County. It's a rural area with the population of about 43,000. In the 2020 election, Donald Trump captured about 70 percent of the vote in this conservative county. It's also the site of a major data breach at the county's elections offices involving some of the most vocal conspiracy theorists in the Trump orbit.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: The story of Coffee County was really under the radar. There was this effort to gain access to voting systems specifically in Georgia. Trump wanted to find evidence of fraud, to find evidence that would support some of his baseless conspiracy theories that he was pushing. And the idea was once you get a copy of the voting system, then you can produce the evidence that there was widespread fraud.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Coffee County seen as a Trump friendly area became a target for those looking to access voting systems.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: January 7th, 2021 was the day that they finally were let in the front doors.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And it was all caught on tape.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: Technicians from the data services firm Sullivan-Stickler were let in to the elections office by Cathy Latham who at the time was the chairwoman of the Republican Party in Coffee County and who a couple weeks earlier had served as one of the 16 fake electors in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Latham initially denied the election equipment had been accessed until security footage proved otherwise. And evidence now shows Latham communicated directly with the then election supervisor in Coffee County about getting access to the office.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: You see on the surveillance video they spent hours inside this restricted room in the elections office.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: They being Scott Hall and Paul Maggio. Hall is an Atlanta area bail bondsman who served as a poll watcher and is an ardent Trump supporter. Maggio works for Sullivan-Strickler, the data firm hired to gain access to the records.In a statement to CNN, Sullivan-Strickler said the firm was directed by the attorneys who hired them to obtain access to certain data and distribute it to certain individuals. And quote, "The firm had no reason to believe these attorneys would ask or direct Sullivan- Strickler to do anything either improper or illegal."

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Ultimately they were able to basically take an entire copy of the voting system with the idea that it would be used to, you know, point to vulnerabilities, point to different issues with the voting machines themselves. And the plan was to use that as evidence of widespread voter fraud.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Another shocking twist in the story? The Coffee County data breach would remain secret for 20 months.(On-camera): When did you guys learn that there was, you know, a potential breach involving Coffee County?

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: About a year after it happened. And when we heard about this, at first it actually got sprung on us in a lawsuit.MURRAY (voice-over): That lawsuit, which is unrelated to the 2020 election, was filed in 2017 after an independent coalition initially sued the secretary of state over the security of the Georgia voting system. The video of the data breach was one piece of evidence in that civil suit. But it revealed exactly what these Trump supporters were up to after he lost the state.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: That person was Scott Hall, the man seen here in the surveillance footage.

utterances.speaker: SCOTT HALL, ATLANTA AREA BAIL BONDSMAN
utterances.sentences: I'm the guy that chartered the jet to go down to Coffee County to have them inspect all of those computers. They scanned all the equipment, imaged all the hard drives and scanned every single ballot.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Without that reporting on Scott Hall, we'd probably never know what we know now.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The Georgia Bureau of Investigation has been looking into the incident since the summer of 2022 and says that their investigation is still ongoing.(On-camera): Did you have any sense this was tied to maybe other operatives in the Trump campaign, that it was anything beyond sort of lower level people in Coffee County?

utterances.speaker: RAFFENSPERGER
utterances.sentences: Not initially. But there were allegations. And as you dig down, more is revealed. And then you realize that that wasn't truthful.

utterances.speaker: HALLERMAN
utterances.sentences: Sidney Powell was the one who ended up commissioning the services of Sullivan-Stricker.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Her involvement is really what exposes the broader Trump team's involvement in Coffee County.MURRAY (voice-over): Powell advocated seizing voting machines with an executive order from Trump at an explosive White House meeting in December 2020.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.sentences: Another idea that was pitched during that meeting was raised by Rudy Giuliani, and he thought that they could coerce or convince local election officials to give their investigators access to voting systems.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: In other words, exactly what happened in Coffee County on January 7th, 2021.(On-camera): Do you feel like, I mean, the longer this goes on, does it ever sort of feel like, wow, this is bigger than even we realized at the time?

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: I think when you start with the president of the United States saying the election was stolen, nothing outside of that is going to be surprising at that point. At this point, nothing is surprising.MURRAY (voice-over): Despite searching for evidence that would back up their theories of election fraud, there's no indication there were any voting irregularities discovered during the data breach. And to this day, we don't know where the data lives and how exactly the Trump supporters planned to use it. Up next --

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: We are about to have the David and Goliath fight.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The extraordinary challenges of trying to indict a former president.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: After nine weeks of countless misleading comments, half- truths, and flat-out lies, a violent, deadly insurrection exploded at the nation's Capitol.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's over.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: In the midst of the riot, then lieutenant governor of Georgia, Geoff Duncan, begged residents of his state involved to stand down.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: I want to speak directly to Georgians. Every Georgian that can hear my voice. Put down your differences. Put down your partisanship.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: More than 20 Georgia residents would go on to face charges, stemming from their actions in Washington, D.C. on January 6th, according to a CNN tally.

utterances.speaker: DUNCAN
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump stopped caring about this country the moment he started lying about that election. The conspiracy theories that literally seeded the beginnings and endings of January 6th in my personal opinion was a direct attack against democracy itself.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: The election lies and conspiracy theories may have reached their apex on January 6th, but even now, more than two years later, Donald Trump refuses to acknowledge the 2020 election results.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: It was a rigged election.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And still can't accept his loss in Georgia.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We have elections that were horrible. If you look at what happened in Atlanta, millions of votes, and all you have to do is take a look at government cameras.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Even as the Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis is expected to ask a grand jury for multiple indictments after investigating efforts to overturn the election results in Georgia. Local officials fear another Trump indictment could spark violence, especially among the Trump supporters who still believe the last election was stolen.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: If January 6th was sort of the result of somebody dropping a few drops of gas on the fire, then I think that these indictments could be basically like turning open the pump and really, really causing some problems. I think that we will see a number of sort of far-right fringe groups become much more active.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: If these radical, vicious, racist prosecutors do anything wrong or illegal, I hope we are going to have in this country the biggest protest we have ever had in Washington, D.C., in New York, in Atlanta, and elsewhere, because our country and our elections are corrupt.

utterances.speaker: CHIDI
utterances.sentences: He has some supporters who will demonstrate in the street in front of the courthouse. There's a capacity for violence in the far- right that cannot be dismissed.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: This fake case was brought only to interfere with the upcoming 2024 election.

utterances.speaker: JACK SMITH, DOJ SPECIAL COUNSEL
utterances.sentences: We have one set of laws in this country, and they apply to everyone.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I consider it a badge, a great, great beautiful badge of honor and courage because I'm being indicted for you.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: A third indictment in Georgia would only intensify the already unprecedented moment in American history. All as the special counsel plows ahead with another federal probe into Trump's efforts to subvert the peaceful transfer of power after the 2020 election.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I ran twice, I won twice.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: In Georgia, it isn't just former President Donald Trump prosecutors are looking at. We know they are considering racketeering and conspiracy charges, allowing the district attorney to bring charges against multiple defendants who took part in the former president's plot.

utterances.speaker: JAMES
utterances.sentences: Here's the Armageddon scenario, all right? There's this RICO indictment, and there's several public officials that are indicted and that are -- you know, that are brought into this indictment. Every one of them is going to have their own army and team of lawyers, and every one of them is going to be filing all of these motions. And you're going to have to respond to all of them.MURRAY (on-camera): If she does bring charges and this does go to trial, what do you think the biggest hurdle for Willis is going to be?

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Her biggest hurdle is going to be, can she get a conviction with jurors who essentially are going to be like a snapshot of the electorate?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The ridiculous and baseless indictment of me by the Biden administration's weaponized department of injustice will go down as among the most horrific abuses of power in the history of our country.

utterances.speaker: JAMES
utterances.sentences: This is not going to be an easy win. I don't care how compelling or how strong your evidence is, how many tapes you have, how many witnesses you have.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And Trump isn't just a former president. He's also the leading Republican candidate for 2024.(On-camera): How does it feel now to see, you know, obviously Donald Trump is running for the White House again?

utterances.speaker: RAFFENSPERGER
utterances.sentences: More of the same. A lot of noise that's not supported by the facts.MURRAY (voice-over): But his candidacy is a point he could try to use to his advantage in the courtroom. (On-camera): If you're Donald Trump in this, how do you juggle the court dates, again, two, three, four indictments with campaigning for president of the United States?

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think that's going to be a legitimate issue he brings up to the court. And while we all want to see some resolution, I don't think there's any question that he's got a good, credible case to make that he shouldn't be forced now to have to try his case in the middle of a presidential primary.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: What happens if he's re-elected president of the United States before these cases are decided?

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: I think that he's immune at least from prosecution in the state court. I think in the federal system, it's a different question altogether. If he were elected, he does hold sort of the ultimate pardon pen. And the question is the same as we got to at the end of his last term, and that is, does he have the authority to pardon himself?MURRAY (voice-over): We're more than two years past the pressure campaign, the harassment of public and private citizens, the coordinating of fake electors, the breach of election equipment. And we still don't know, will Trump and his allies face charges here in Georgia? And if so, will there be convictions?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They rigged the presidential election in 2020, and we're not going to allow them to rig the presidential election of 2024.MURRAY (on-camera): Did voters deserve an answer to this question before Donald Trump became, you know, an announced candidate again?

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Yes. I don't think there's any question about that. I mean -- so from a national perspective, no question about it. From a local perspective here, no question about it.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: Do you see any risk in moving forward with an indictment of the former president? I mean, are we setting any kind of a dangerous precedent?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: I think we're setting a dangerous precedent if we don't move forward. If we don't hold him accountable, I think the risk is much more significant.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: We saw former President Trump lie to the American people. We saw him gin up this outrage. Is it a remedy if he's charged with a crime in Georgia?

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: If they indict him and they can't convict him, it will be an exoneration. Is that better or is that worse? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: What message does it send if they don't -- if you don't bring charges against someone who tried to overturn the results, who, you know, allowed these sort of threats to permeate?

utterances.speaker: STERLING
utterances.sentences: Again, there's no good solutions here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIS
utterances.sentences: What I could envision is that we actually live in a society where Lady Justice is blind and that it doesn't matter if you're rich, poor, black, white, Democrat, or Republican. If you violated the law, you're going to be charged.(END VIDEOTAPE)
